03.01.question: Yuri wants to interview both managers and staff in the accounting department for the updated credit analysis project. This is an appropriate group for first round interviews.

03.02.question: Typically, interviews do not include the following type questions:

03.03.question: Paul is interviewing Ming. He first explains why he is there and what he wants to accomplish in the interview. This would be done in which step of the interview process?

03.04.question: Practical tips states that interpersonal skills are important, they include which of the following?

03.05.question: To get to more depth in understanding the as-is system, document analysis and observation generally are more beneficial as compared to interviews and JAD sessions.

03.06.question: Online questionnaires are growing in use, but generally online questionnaires have a lower completion rate.

03.07.question: When an analyst is seeking more information from a response to questions they would probably use which type of question?

03.08.question: A JAD facilitator recognizes that some people know more about the system and proposed system and will dominate the discussion and know that is a positive thing.

03.09.question: One of the first activities of an analyst is to determine the business requirements for the new system.

03.10.question: A JAD facilitator can participate in the discussion to settle a disagreement.

03.11.question: When eliciting requirements from processing clerks and lower level managers about 'how' a system works, the best approach might be: _____.

03.12.question: Rafael, Fraud Unit Manager, has just received an interview report from Stefano, a systems analyst. Rafael was interviewed by Stefano, and was asked to make corrections and clarifications to the interview report. In what interview phase would this occur?

03.13.question: Generally beginning analysts should avoid unstructured interviews and likewise should avoid "winging it".

03.14.question: In interviews, Ross has learned that the new order entry system must be available in at least three formats (mobile, web browser, and local area network based); that it must function in either English or Spanish; and that the system must return order forms and data in less than 2 seconds. He recognizes these as nonfunctional requirements.

03.15.question: Interpersonal skills are those that enable a person to develop a rapport and are important for interviewing.

03.16.question: An example of a nonfunctional requirement is ____________

03.16.A.choice: System can be used in any of 100 offices worldwide

03.16.B.choice: SQL queries from customer table and order table are available

03.16.C.choice: Customer zipcode is formatted as character data

03.16.E.choice: The system must contain customer order history for three years

03.17.question: In preparing for an interview, TJ does research as to areas in which the interviewee has knowledge so that he does not ask questions that an interviewee cannot answer.

03.18.question: In the interview report, what will probably NOT be included?

03.18.B.choice: Summary of what the interviewee said

03.18.C.choice: Details from crucial areas of the interview relating to the project at hand

03.18.D.choice: The actual questions that were asked as a permanent record

03.18.E.choice: Any materials, documents, etc. that the interviewee gave you relevant to the project at hand

03.19.question: A JAD facilitator keeps track of all discussions by entering information into the computer.

03.20.question: Which is generally NOT true of non-functional requirements?

03.20.B.choice: Systems may need to adapt from global solutions to local realities

03.20.C.choice: Color interpretations on screens and forms may be different in different geographical places

03.20.E.choice: Systems may need to have actual expenses from global operations

03.21.question: The SDLC moves from the current system (often called the "past system") to the new system (often called the "future system").

03.22.question: The authors suggest that an analyst is 'very much like a ____________' and business users are like elusive suspects.

03.23.question: Generally 'system requirements' are developed in the analysis phase and evolve to more technical 'business requirements' in the design phase.

03.24.question: Michael, a systems analyst, is preparing a closed wiki site for Northstate Bank. He has written permission from eight other companies to view their internal wiki sites, and also has approval from his manager and the project team to use these other sites for ideas and structure. This would be a form of:

03.25.question: The most important purpose of the requirements definition is to define the scope of the system.

03.26.question: The line between analysis and design is sometimes very blurry. One reason is that _____:

03.26.B.choice: the deliverables are really the first step in the design of the new system

03.26.C.choice: object-oriented methods are generally fuzzier as compared to waterfall methods

03.26.D.choice: there is inadequate funding for the analysis phase to do a complete analysis

03.26.E.choice: analysts are generally rushed to complete the system proposal

03.27.question: Which is NOT a requirements analysis strategy?

03.27.A.choice: Developing requirements for the to-be system

03.27.B.choice: Understanding of screen design, layout and navigation

03.28.question: A technique where a set of written questions are distributed to people (frequently to a large number of people) is: _____.

03.29.question: Cindi Flores distributed 'white-papers' on RFID, ERP, GPS and SOA to a user-management group. She then asked them to 'think outside the box' on where these technologies could be used in the company. This would be an example of "technology analysis."

03.30.question: What information-eliciting strategy enables the analyst to see the reality of the situation rather than listen to others describe it?

03.31.question: Which is NOT a good practice in conducting interviews?

03.31.A.choice: Watch interviewees' facial expressions, how they sit and their body language; do they cross their arms; do they lean forward?

03.31.B.choice: Pay attention to what the interviewee is saying

03.31.C.choice: Explain thoroughly – it is estimated that in a strong interview session, the interviewer (you) should talk and explain about 60% of the time; and the interviewee should answer about 40% of the time

03.31.D.choice: Be happy – happy people radiate confidence

03.31.E.choice: If the interviewee ask you a question, answer it truthfully – and if you don't know an answer, say so

03.32.question: One of the major differences between a JAD session and an interview is what?

03.32.A.choice: Figuring out what is to be done

03.32.C.choice: All JAD sessions are structured and must be carefully planned

03.32.E.choice: Writing up results and a report

03.33.question: An example of a functional requirement is _________

03.33.A.choice: Access to the customer order system

03.33.B.choice: System should be available in English and Spanish

03.33.C.choice: Output can be displayed in Internet Explorer, in Firefox, or in Google Chrome browsers

03.33.D.choice: System is automatically updated every 5 seconds

03.33.E.choice: System can be accessed through a Blackberry device

03.34.question: Management of requirements and system scope is one of the hardest parts of managing a project.

03.35.question: In RAD or agile development methodology (especially with BPR), a significant amount of time and effort is spent in understanding the as-is system.

03.36.question: Probably the first thing to do when conducting an interview is:

03.36.D.choice: Get started by asking the first question on your list

03.36.E.choice: Build rapport with the interviewee so he or she trusts you

03.37.question: One difference between the reports from interviews and from a JAD session is that:

03.37.A.choice: The interview report will give a complete project management timeline; while the JAD session report will not

03.37.B.choice: JAD reports will include technology analysis while interviews will only include root cause analysis

03.37.C.choice: The JAD report will include results from questionnaires while the interview report will not

03.37.D.choice: It describes information from the interview or JAD session

03.37.E.choice: The interview report is generally written within 48 hours of the interview; while the JAD session report may take a week or two after the JAD session.

03.38.question: Which is NOT a purpose of the requirements definition?

03.38.A.choice: A more precise list of requirements that can be used as inputs to the rest of analysis

03.38.C.choice: To give a very high-level explanation of the business requirements

03.39.question: Most existing systems are well documented which leads to document analysis being very valuable.

03.40.question: After creating the interview report you should:

03.40.A.choice: Edit the report into a bulleted format for easier analysis

03.40.B.choice: Change the document into a unchangeable format (like a pdf file) so that it cannot be changed or edited

03.40.C.choice: Distribute the interview report to all others that are on the interview schedule so they will not have to go over the same materials

03.40.D.choice: Distribute the interview report to the interviewee's manager.

03.40.E.choice: Send a copy to the interviewee with a request to read it and correct or clarify

03.41.question: When an analyst is looking for specific, precise information they would probably choose this type of question:

03.42.question: An interview report is prepared in which step of the interview process?

03.43.question: Danielle has asked some closed-ended questions to start an interview; then some open-ended questions. Now, she wants to really wants to get a greater depth of information about the process. She would probably use _________ questions.

03.44.question: When eliciting requirements, the most commonly used technique is: __________

03.45.question: Blaine is using a requirements eliciting technique that begins with non-threatening questions, avoids abbreviations, groups items into logically coherent sections, and might best be used with outside users. He probably is using what?

03.46.question: The most commonly used requirements elicitation technique is the interview.

03.47.question: Marta wants to focus on 'why' a particular lockout situation occurs on a customer relationship management system, rather than just developing a work-around fix. She is doing activity elimination.

03.48.question: Gary has eight interviews to conduct over the next week. Once he has completed all interviews, he should then write up a summary report. Preparing interview reports prior to completing all interviews will generally be premature until Gary has talked to all interviewees.

03.49.question: What does it mean for a process to be fragmented?

03.49.A.choice: The major steps required to complete the process cost too much.

03.49.B.choice: There are too many steps required to complete the process.

03.49.C.choice: There are too many actors involved in completing the process.

03.49.D.choice: The major steps in the process are completed in parallel.

03.50.question: In terms of reaching the most number of people in requirements elicitation, interviews are considered better than questionnaires.

03.51.question: Jorge, Vice President of Operations, has requested that the updated supply chain system keep a record of all 'stock-outs' for six years. This is an example of a functional requirement.

03.52.question: Myles is studying a system to lessen the number of complaints about the Help Desk. He has formally studied the service counter at Wal-Mart, Target and Kohl's department stores; as well as listened in to complaint phone calls to a hotel booking site. He is trying to see how other organizations work at lessening complaints and also how they handle complaints. This would be what type of analysis?

03.53.question: The requirements-elicitation process is used for building financial support for the project and establishing common understanding of technologies and rapport between the project team building the system and the users of the system.

03.54.question: When an analyst is seeking a more wide ranging response to questions they would probably use which type of question?

03.55.question: A JAD facilitator allows sidebar discussions and unstructured activities.

03.56.question: Miski has modified an existing time reporting system for hourly employees to be more efficient as they can text message when they are leaving a job site. This would be an example of Business Process Automation.

03.57.question: One person dominating the group discussion of a JAD session will normally lead to a positive outcome.

03.58.question: Maria, a systems analyst, is tweaking the high-level explanation of the business requirements into a more precise list of requirements. This is called 'requirements determination'.

03.59.question: Your company updated its processes for financial reporting when Sarbanes-Oxley became law. Additional changes in Sarbanes-Oxley reporting have been mandated to start in one year. To help you understand the as-is system, you should review the documentation, processes and procedures that were developed with the initial Sarbanes-Oxley project.

03.60.question: Which of the following types of questions are close-ended?

03.61.question: The three types of interview questions are: multiple choice, fill in the blank and short answer.

03.62.question: Marta wants to collect facts and opinions from a wide range of geographically dispersed people quickly and with the least expense. She would probably want to use what?

03.63.question: Which of the following will probably NOT be at a system walkthrough?

03.63.B.choice: Analyst who prepared the system proposal

03.64.question: A JAD facilitator sets the meeting agenda.

03.65.question: Hamid has selected one middle manager from each department that will be affected by the updated system and one lower-level manager from each department, along with a few senior staff as well as the project sponsor for a JAD session. He is trying to do what?

03.65.A.choice: Create a new hybrid department that will beta test the final system

03.65.B.choice: Balance the work load for departments so the regular day-to-day functions can still continue while the JAD team is off-site

03.65.C.choice: Have a broad mix of organizational levels in the JAD session

03.65.D.choice: Prevent domination by only a few individuals in the JAD session

03.65.E.choice: Reduce the time necessary for the length of JAD session meetings

03.66.question: Some people have suggested that the 'analysis' phase could be clearer if it was called the 'analysis and initial design' phase.

03.67.question: A technique where the analyst watches how people perform their activities is _______

03.68.question: The interview process has gone well. There are a few things that need clarification and what really happens when specific financial analysts use the system. Which of the following might be the best way to verify what does happen?

03.68.A.choice: Document analysis of what the system was to do

03.68.B.choice: Additional interviews with top level managers in the finance area

03.68.C.choice: Observation of how the analysts do their work

03.68.D.choice: A JAD session with end users, financial analysts and top managers

03.68.E.choice: Questionnaires / survey of end users of the system

03.69.question: Unless ordered by the lead analyst for a project, you should not share your interview report with those that you interviewed. Doing so will almost always result in scope creep and changes in the requirements.

03.70.question: Rebecca, a fairly new employee in the company and Matt, her boss (who has been with the company for 22 years) are in your JAD session. It would probably be expected that Rebecca would not share much in the session.

03.71.question: According to the authors, in moving "from here to there", an analyst needs:

03.71.D.choice: Knowledge on how to stop scope creep

03.72.question: To create the requirements definition, the project team first should consider the kinds of functional and non-functional requirements that they will collect about the system.
